comment.author: 64848937@N00
comment._content: Rostrevor is also the site of an ancient SSSI woodland.  Very much a gem of Ireland's natural world.

comment.author: 8623220@N02
comment._content: Thanks for spotting the lost punctuation. Woodside might be the name of a hotel in Rostrevor, so going with a comma for now. Hopefully we'll hear more soon about the buildings in the scene.

comment.author: 51588910@N08
comment._content: The hotel is (was) the Great Northern Hotel - Woodside is correct however it refers to an area slightly further back in the picture. The building itself was destroyed in a fire bomb attack in the late 1970's and was never rebuilt. The site is now a car showroom. There are many photographs of the area and some of them along with a photo of a tiny fragment of the old horse drawn tram rails remains and can be seen here: www.oldwarrenpointforum.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=4&...

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content: Brian McCalmont, Thank you for the further information on this image! Your link was helpful, as it led me to search in the National Library of Ireland's digital photographs. There is a photograph similar to this view in the National Library of Ireland's collections , and it is identified: Woodside, Rostrevor, Down, so it seems we can safely stay with our current identification. Thanks again for the comment.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: 2008 view from Google Street View: maps.google.com/maps?q=Rostrevor,+United+Kingdom&hl=e... The hotel was the Mourne Hotel in the 1890-1900 timeframe of this Photochrom. Here's a view from past the hotel, looking towards where the Photochrom was taken, showing the tram line in use. www.oldwarrenpointforum.com/phpBB3/viewtopic.php?f=12&amp...
